Hello All!

Last night I downloaded the Demo for KSP and have been hooked every since. Bought the full version after less than 24 hours playing in the demo. I figured I'd drop in and say hello while I wait for the game to unzip. Here's hoping I can achieve orbit for Kerbin before too much longer. I've been browsing the tips section already and know I'll be having tons of fun!

-Speedo

(It's a roller derby name in case your curious)

Wonder when Skunky will respond. I wonder if he just makes a bot do the responds...I think they're...

...watching...us...

First thanks for the welcome!! I've had tons of fun flying (and crashing) several rockets. When I made my first orbit I was ecstatic.

Second, A quick question. Fuel flows from a tank in to an engine right... Does fuel flow between two tanks stacked one on top of another or do I need to use fuel pipes?

Fuel automatically cross feeds between tanks starting from the top down. Also, be aware that RCS monoprop will cross feed across stack couplers and drain from the top tank as well. To save its fuel for your probe or command module stage for later in your flight, you can disable the tank with a right click and click on the fuel option until you need it. That way, the thrusters will use fuel from the lower tank. Fuel lines are only needed when you want to connect tanks or engines across stack couplers for specific needs such as asparagus or onion staging and for drop tanks.

Here is a tip, try to start on a simplistic design, test different variables of it, and when you finally get into orbit, but can't exactly get to the moon, just add more fuel, and you might just get there. Also, welcome to the KSP forums.

Have fun with your flights!

Thanks for the tip Naten. I am going through the KSP campaigns and am at the point where it wants me to do geostationary orbits and a quick google search point me toward Kerbal engineer and MechJeb. MechJeb seems a little overkill for me at this point.
